sen.j: 足利 義詮（あしかが よしあきら、元徳2年6月18日 (旧暦)（1330年7月4日） - 正平 (日本)22年/貞治6年12月7日 (旧暦)（1367年12月28日））は、室町幕府2代征夷大将軍。
sen.e: Yoshiakira ASHIKAGA (June 18, Gentoku 2 (old calendar – July 4, 1330 AD) to December 7, Shohei 22/Joji 6 (old calendar – December 28, 1367 AD) was the 2nd Seii Taishogun of the Muromachi Shogunate.
Yoshiakira ASHIKAGA-July 4, 1330 AD to December 28, 1367 AD-was the 2nd Seii Taishogun of the Muromachi Shogunate.
sen.cmt: 旧暦を入れると、文章全体がごちゃごちゃとして読みにくいので、西暦のみにしました。 征夷大将軍→Seii-Taishogun is a shogun in charge of conquering barbarian territories.
sen.e: Yoshiakira ASHIKAGA-July 4, 1330 AD to December 28, 1367 AD-was the 2nd Seii Taishogun of the Muromachi Shogunate.

sen.j: 足利尊氏の第三子で嫡男。
sen.e: He was the 3rd child and heir of Takauji ASHIKAGA.
He was the 3rd child and heir of Takauji ASHIKAGA.
He was the 3rd child and heir of Takauji ASHIKAGA.

sen.j: 母は北条久時の娘の赤橋登子で、鎌倉幕府最後の執権北条守時の妹に当る。
sen.e: His mother, Touko AKAHASHI, was the daughter of Hisatoki HOJO, and the sister of the last regent to the Kamakura Shogunate, Moritoki HOJO.
His mother, Touko AKAHASHI, was the daughter of Hisatoki HOJO, and the younger sister of the last regent to the Kamakura Shogunate, Moritoki HOJO.
His mother, Touko AKAHASHI, was the daughter of Hisatoki HOJO, and the younger sister of the last regent to the Kamakura Shogunate, Moritoki HOJO.

sen.j: 正室は渋川義季の娘の渋川幸子。
sen.e: His wife was Sachiko SHIBUKAWA, the daughter of Yoshisue SHIBUKAWA.
His wife was Koshi SHIBUKAWA, the daughter of Yoshisue SHIBUKAWA.
sen.cmt: 渋川幸子→Koshi SHIBUKAWA ウィキペディアには、しぶかわ こうしとある。他資料は見つからず。
sen.e: His wife was Koshi SHIBUKAWA, the daughter of Yoshisue SHIBUKAWA.

sen.j: 幼名は千寿王（せんじゅおう）。
sen.e: His name in childhood was Senjuou.
His name in childhood was Senjuou.
His name in childhood was Senjuou.

sen.j: 子に足利義満、足利満詮など。
sen.e: Yoshimitsu ASHIKAGA and Mitsuakira ASHIKAGA were among his children.
Yoshimitsu ASHIKAGA and Mitsuakira ASHIKAGA were among his children.
Yoshimitsu ASHIKAGA and Mitsuakira ASHIKAGA were among his children.

sen.j: 官位は正二位大納言、従一位左大臣。
sen.e: His official ranks were Councilor of State Senior 2nd Class, and Minister of the Left Junior 1st Class.
His official ranks were Sho-Nii Dainagon (Senior 2nd Class Chief Councillor of State), and Ju-Ichii Sadaijin (Junior 1st Class Minister of the Left).
sen.cmt: 大納言→Chief Councillor of State 大納言や左大臣は、日本独特の用語なので、一応日本語も入れましたが、必要無しと判断されるなら省略して下さい。官位の名前の順序も原文に準じました。
sen.e: His official ranks were Sho-Nii Dainagon (Senior 2nd Class Chief Councillor of State), and Ju-Ichii Sadaijin (Junior 1st Class Minister of the Left).

tit.j: 幼少時から将軍就任まで

sen.j: 伯耆国船上山にて挙兵した後醍醐天皇討伐のために父・尊氏が鎌倉幕府軍の総大将として上洛した際、母・登子とともに北条氏の人質として鎌倉へ留め置かれる。
sen.e: When his father, Takauji, went to the capital as general commander of the Kamakura Shogunate's army to suppress the force that Emperor Godaigo was raising on Mt. Senjo in Houki Province, he and his mother, Touko, were held in Kamakura as hostages of the Hojo clan.

When his father, Takauji, went to the capital as a general commander of the Kamakura Shogunate's army to suppress the force that Emperor Godaigo was raising on Mt. Senjo in Houki Province, he and his mother, Touko, were held in Kamakura as hostages of the Hojo clan.

When his father, Takauji, went to the capital as a general commander of the Kamakura Shogunate's army to suppress the force that Emperor Godaigo was raising on Mt. Senjo in Houki Province, he and his mother, Touko, were held in Kamakura as hostages of the Hojo clan.

sen.j: 尊氏が丹波国で鎌倉幕府に反旗を翻し、京都の六波羅探題を攻略すると、幼い義詮（千寿王）は、細川氏などの足利家家臣に連れ出され鎌倉を脱出し、新田義貞に奉じられ鎌倉攻めに参加した。
sen.e: When Takauji raised the standard of revolt against the Kamakura Shogunate in Tanba province and captured Kyoto's Rokuhara Tandai, young Yoshiakira (Senjuou) fled Kamakura, carried away by Hosokawa and other Ashikaga vassals, and with Yoshisada NITTA participated in the attack on Kamakura.
sen.cmt: 六波羅探題→Rokuhara Tandai was the post of the chiefs of the Kamakura shogunate in Kyoto. とあり。
sen.e: When Takauji raised the standard of revolt against the Kamakura Shogunate in Tanba province and captured Kyoto's Rokuhara Tandai, young Yoshiakira (Senjuou) fled Kamakura, carried away by Hosokawa and other Ashikaga vassals, and with Yoshisada NITTA participated in the attack on Kamakura.

When Takauji raised the standard of revolt against the Kamakura Shogunate in Tanba province and captured Kyoto's Rokuhara Tandai, young Yoshiakira (Senjuou) fled Kamakura, carried away by Hosokawa and other Ashikaga vassals, and with Yoshisada NITTA participated in the attack on Kamakura.

sen.j: この際千寿王は、父・尊氏の名代として、家臣らの補佐により、鎌倉攻め参加の武士に対し軍忠状を発付し、後に足利氏が武家の棟梁として認知される端緒を作る。
sen.e: On that occasion Senjuou acted as his father's representative and issued a certificate of loyal service for the aid of the vassals, thereby marking the beginning of the Ashikaga's later recognition as supporter of the samurai.

On that occasion Senjuou acted as his father's representative and issued a certificate of loyal service to the samurai of the Kamakura attack participation with the assistance of the vassals, thereby marking the beginning of the Ashikaga's later recognition as a leader of the samurai.
sen.cmt: 原文の”鎌倉攻め参加の武士に対し”という部分の訳が抜けているので補足→to the samurai of the Kamakura attack participation for the aid of the vassals→with the assistance of the vassals に修正。 棟梁は、supporter というよりleader とした方が適切だと思うので修正。
sen.e: On that occasion Senjuou acted as his father's representative and issued a certificate of loyal service to the samurai of the Kamakura attack participation with the assistance of the vassals, thereby marking the beginning of the Ashikaga's later recognition as a leader of the samurai.

sen.j: 建武の新政では、叔父である足利直義に支えられて鎌倉に置かれ、尊氏が建武政権から離反すると、父とともに南朝 (日本)と戦い、主に鎌倉において関東を統治した。
sen.e: Under the new Kenmu government he was placed in Kamakura with the support of his uncle, Tadayoshi ASHIKAGA, and fought the Southern Dynasty (Japan) alongside his father when Takauji became alienated from the Kenmu regime, mostly ruling the Kanto region from Kamakura.

Under the new Kenmu government he was placed in Kamakura with the support of his uncle, Tadayoshi ASHIKAGA, and fought the Southern Dynasty (Japan) alongside his father when Takauji became alienated from the Kenmu regime, mostly ruling the Kanto region in Kamakura.
sen.cmt: 原文に、(鎌倉に)おいて、とあるのでfrom→in に修正。
sen.e: Under the new Kenmu government he was placed in Kamakura with the support of his uncle, Tadayoshi ASHIKAGA, and fought the Southern Dynasty (Japan) alongside his father when Takauji became alienated from the Kenmu regime, mostly ruling the Kanto region in Kamakura.

sen.j: 尊氏による足利幕府開府後、足利家の執事である高師直と尊氏の弟の足利直義の対立が激化して観応の擾乱が起こり、師直のクーデタにより直義が失脚すると、義詮は京都へ呼び戻され直義に代わり幕府の政務を任される。
sen.e: After Takauji established the Ashikaga Shogunate, the opposition intensified between the Ashikaga family's regent, Moronao KO, and Takauji's brother, Tadayoshi ASHIKAGA, and lead to the Kanno Disturbance; then Tadayoshi fell to Moronao's coup and Yoshiakira was recalled to Kyoto and assumed control of the Shogunate in Tadayoshi's place.
sen.cmt: 観応の擾乱は以下のホームページ参照http://books.google.co.jp/books?ct=result&as_brr=3&id=Hv99D510nHcC&dq=Ashikaga%E3%80%80Kanno&ots=sF3MFl7WWH&pg=PA69&lpg=PA69&sig=ACfU3U13HfnhLI5xvqMW7o4B7tIv2TKR8w&q=Kanno#PPA68,M1
sen.e: After Takauji established the Ashikaga Shogunate, the opposition intensified between the Ashikaga family's Shituji (Shogun's deputy), Moronao KO, and Takauji's brother, Tadayoshi ASHIKAGA, and led to the Kanno Disturbance; then Tadayoshi fell to Moronao's coup and Yoshiakira was recalled to Kyoto and assumed control of the Shogunate in Tadayoshi's place.
sen.cmt: 足利家の執事は、regent (摂政）では無く、Shogun's deputy (将軍の代理官、復官）の方が良いと思うので修正。 lead→led
sen.e: After Takauji established the Ashikaga Shogunate, the opposition intensified between the Ashikaga family's Shituji (Shogun's deputy), Moronao KO, and Takauji's brother, Tadayoshi ASHIKAGA, and led to the Kanno Disturbance; then Tadayoshi fell to Moronao's coup and Yoshiakira was recalled to Kyoto and assumed control of the Shogunate in Tadayoshi's place.

sen.j: 1351年には、尊氏が直義派に対抗するために義詮と共に南朝に降伏し、年号を南朝の「正平」に統一する正平一統が行われる。
sen.e: In 1351 Takauji and Yoshiakira capitulated to the Southern Dynasty and carried out the Shouhei Unification, changing the name of the era to the Southern Dynasty's "Shouhei", to antagonize the Tadayoshi faction.

In 1351 Takauji and Yoshiakira capitulated to the Southern Dynasty and carried out the Shouhei Unification, changing the name of the era to the Southern Dynasty's "Shouhei", to antagonize the Tadayoshi faction.

In 1351 Takauji and Yoshiakira capitulated to the Southern Dynasty and carried out the Shouhei Unification, changing the name of the era to the Southern Dynasty's "Shouhei", to antagonize the Tadayoshi faction.

sen.j: 翌年に南朝の北畠親房や楠木正儀らが京都へ侵攻すると、義詮は京を逃れて近江国へ避難した結果、光厳天皇、光明天皇、崇光天皇の三太上天皇を奪われたが、観応の年号を復活させるとともに兵を募って京都を奪還し、三種の神器の無い状態で新たに後光厳天皇を即位させる。
sen.e: In the following year the Southern Dynasty's Chikafusa KITABATAKE and Masanori KUSUNOKI invaded Kyoto; and although three former Emperors, Kougon, Komyo, and Suko, were captured because Yoshiakira fled the capital and took refuge in Oumi province, he restored the name of the era to Kanno while recruiting an army to regain Kyoto, and enthroned Emperor Gokougon without the Three Sacred Treasures.

In the following year the Southern Dynasty's Chikafusa KITABATAKE and Masanori KUSUNOKI invaded Kyoto; and although three former Emperors, Kougon, Komyo, and Suko, were captured because Yoshiakira fled the capital and took refuge in Oumi province, he restored the name of the era to Kanno while recruiting an army to regain Kyoto, and enthroned Emperor Gokougon without the Three Sacred Treasures.

In the following year the Southern Dynasty's Chikafusa KITABATAKE and Masanori KUSUNOKI invaded Kyoto; and although three former Emperors, Kougon, Komyo, and Suko, were captured because Yoshiakira fled the capital and took refuge in Oumi province, he restored the name of the era to Kanno while recruiting an army to regain Kyoto, and enthroned Emperor Gokougon without the Three Sacred Treasures.

sen.j: また1353年にも足利直冬や山名時氏らの攻勢により、一時的に京都を奪われている。
sen.e: He briefly lost Kyoto again in 1353 to an attack by Tadafuyu ASHIKAGA and Tokiuji YAMANA.
He briefly lost Kyoto again in 1353 to an attack by Tadafuyu ASHIKAGA and Tokiuji YAMANA.
He briefly lost Kyoto again in 1353 to an attack by Tadafuyu ASHIKAGA and Tokiuji YAMANA.

sen.j: 1358年（正平 (日本)13年/延文3年）に尊氏が没し、義詮は征夷大将軍に任命される。
sen.e: In 1358 (Shohei 13/Enbun 3) Takauji died, and Yoshiakira became the Seii Taishogun.
sen.cmt: 征夷大将軍→Seii-Taishogun is a shogun in charge of conquering barbarian territories. 以下、旧暦が全部訳されているので、あえて削除しなかったのですが、必要無いなら省略して下さい。最初から訳されていなければ、補足はしません。ただし、下記に旧暦のみ表記されている文章もあります。
sen.e: In 1358 (Shohei 13/Enbun 3) Takauji died, and Yoshiakira became the Seii Taishogun.
In 1358 (Shohei 13/Enbun 3) Takauji died, and Yoshiakira became the Seii Taishogun.

sen.j: この頃には中国地方の山名氏や大内氏などが向背定まらず、九州地方では懐良親王などの南朝勢力は健在であった。
sen.e: Around that time the affairs of the Yamana and Ouchi clans of the Chugoku region were in disorder, while the influence of the Southern Dynasty was intact in Prince Kanenaga in Kyushu.
Around that time the affairs of the Yamana and Ouchi clans of the Chugoku region were in disorder, while the influence of the Southern Dynasty such as Prince Kanenaga was intact in Kyushu.
sen.cmt: while the influence of the Southern Dynasty was intact in Prince Kanenaga→while the influence of the Southern Dynasty such as Prince Kanenaga was intact 文章の最後に in が重ならないように修正。
sen.e: Around that time the affairs of the Yamana and Ouchi clans of the Chugoku region were in disorder, while the influence of the Southern Dynasty such as Prince Kanenaga was intact in Kyushu.

sen.j: 更に幕府内では仁木義長と細川清氏・畠山国清が対立し義長は南朝へ降り、さらに室町幕府執事(管領)の清氏が佐々木道誉の讒言で離反して南朝へ降るなど権力抗争が絶えず、その隙を突いて南朝方が一時京都を奪還するなど政権は流動的であった。
sen.e: Furthermore within the Shogunate, Yoshinaga NIKKI opposed Kiyouji HOSOKAWA and Kunihiko HATAKEYAMA and went to the Southern Dynasty; the Kiyo clan, stewards of the Muromachi Shogunate (Kanrei) left for the Southern Dynasty over remarks by Douyo SASAKI; with the Shogunate weakened by power struggles, the Southern Dynasty took the opportunity to briefly regain Kyoto; government was in flux.

Furthermore within the Shogunate, Yoshinaga NIKKI opposed Kiyouji HOSOKAWA and Kunihiko HATAKEYAMA and went to the Southern Dynasty; Kiyouji, a Shogun's deputy (Kanrei) of the Muromachi Shogunate, left for the Southern Dynasty over remarks by Douyo SASAKI; with the Shogunate weakened by power struggles, the Southern Dynasty took the opportunity to briefly regain Kyoto; government was in flux.
sen.cmt: the Kiyo clan→Kiyouji (これは、細川清氏 (名前)を指していると思われる。 管領→Shogun's deputy
sen.e: Furthermore within the Shogunate, Yoshinaga NIKKI opposed Kiyouji HOSOKAWA and Kunihiko HATAKEYAMA and went to the Southern Dynasty; Kiyouji, a Shogun's deputy (Kanrei) of the Muromachi Shogunate, left for the Southern Dynasty over remarks by Douyo SASAKI; with the Shogunate weakened by power struggles, the Southern Dynasty took the opportunity to briefly regain Kyoto; government was in flux.

sen.j: 1363年には大内氏、山名氏が幕府に帰参して政権は安定化しはじめ、南朝との講和も進んでいた。
sen.e: In 1363 the Ouchi and Yamana clans returned to the Shogunate, government began to stabilize, and progress was made toward peace with the Southern Dynasty.
In 1363 the Ouchi and Yamana clans returned to the Shogunate, government began to stabilize, and progress was made toward peace with the Southern Dynasty.
In 1363 the Ouchi and Yamana clans returned to the Shogunate, government began to stabilize, and progress was made toward peace with the Southern Dynasty.

sen.j: 1365年には三条坊門万里小路の新邸に移っている。
sen.e: In 1365 he moved to a new mansion at Sanjo Boumon Madenokoji.
In 1365 he moved to a new mansion at Sanjo Boumon Madenokoji.
In 1365 he moved to a new mansion at Sanjo Boumon Madenokoji.

sen.j: 清氏の失脚以来空席となっていた管領職に斯波義将を任じ、斯波氏が一時失脚すると細川頼之を管領に任命する。
sen.e: Yoshimasa SHIBA filled the position of Kanrei that was left open by the Kiyo clan's fall; then Yoriyuki HOSOKAWA took over when SHIBA fell briefly.
Yoshimasa SHIBA filled the position of Kanrei that was left open by Kiyouji's fall; then Yoriyuki HOSOKAWA took over when SHIBA fell briefly.
sen.cmt: the Kiyo clan's→Kiyouji's 人の名前なので修正。
sen.e: Yoshimasa SHIBA filled the position of Kanrei that was left open by Kiyouji's fall; then Yoriyuki HOSOKAWA took over when SHIBA fell briefly.

sen.j: また、訴訟手続の整備なども行う。
sen.e: He also consolidated legal proceedings.
He also consolidated legal proceedings.
He also consolidated legal proceedings.

sen.j: 1367年（正平22年/貞治6年）に、側室の紀良子との間に生まれた幼少の嫡男義満を細川頼之に託して、病により死去する。
sen.e: In 1367 (Shohei 22/Joji 6) he entrusted his heir, Yoshimitsu, who was born to him by his concubine, Yoshiko KI, to Yoriyuki HOSOKAWA, then succumbed to illness and died.
In 1367 (Shohei 22/Joji 6) he entrusted his heir, Yoshimitsu, who was born to him by his concubine, KI no Yoshiko, to Yoriyuki HOSOKAWA, then succumbed to illness and died.
sen.cmt: Yoshiko KI→KI no Yoshiko 指示書に従い修正。
sen.e: In 1367 (Shohei 22/Joji 6) he entrusted his heir, Yoshimitsu, who was born to him by his concubine, KI no Yoshiko, to Yoriyuki HOSOKAWA, then succumbed to illness and died.

sen.j: 享年38。
sen.e: Aged 38.
Aged 38.
Aged 38.

sen.j: 同年3月5日 (旧暦)には弟基氏が義詮に先立ってなくなっている。
sen.e: His brother, Motouji, died before him on March 5th (old calendar) of the same year.
His brother, Motouji, died before him on March 5th (old calendar) of the same year.
His brother, Motouji, died before him on March 5th (old calendar) of the same year.

sen.j: 彼の遺言に「自分の逝去後、かねており敬慕していた観林寺（現在の善入山宝筐院）の楠木正行の墓の傍らで眠らせてもらいたい。
sen.e: His last request was "after I die, let me rest beside the grave of my beloved Masatsura KUSUNOKI at Kanrin-ji Temple" (present day Zennyuzan Hokyoin Temple).
His last request was "after I die, let me rest beside the grave of my beloved Masatsura KUSUNOKI at Kanrin-ji Temple" (present day Zennyuzan Hokyoin Temple).
His last request was "after I die, let me rest beside the grave of my beloved Masatsura KUSUNOKI at Kanrin-ji Temple" (present day Zennyuzan Hokyoin Temple).

sen.j: 」とあり、遺言どおり、楠木正行の墓（五輪石塔）の隣に彼の墓（宝筐印塔）は建てられた。
sen.e: His grave (Hokyointo) was put next to that of Masatsura KUSUNOKI (Gorinsekito), in accordance with his will.
His grave (Hokyointo) was put next to that of Masatsura KUSUNOKI (Gorinsekito), in accordance with his will.
His grave (Hokyointo) was put next to that of Masatsura KUSUNOKI (Gorinsekito), in accordance with his will.

sen.j: 法名寶篋院瑞山道權
sen.e: Posthumously named Hokyoin Zuisandogon
Posthumously named Hokyoin Zuizandogon.
sen.cmt: 寶篋院は、"ほうきょういん”との資料あり。瑞山は、”ずいざん”という人の名前があるとの資料あり。道權のみ、資料見つからず。しかしこのまま素直に読むと"どうごん”となるようです。確証無し。
sen.e: Posthumously named Hokyoin Zuizandogon.

sen.j: 墓所京都府京都市北区 (京都市)の萬年山等持院。
sen.e: His gravesite is at Mannenzan Toujiin Temple in Kyoto's Kita Ward.
His gravesite is at Mannenzan Toujiin Temple in Kita Ward, Kyoto City, Kyoto Prefecture.
sen.cmt: 京都府京都市北区とあるので補足。
sen.e: His gravesite is at Mannenzan Toujiin Temple in Kita Ward, Kyoto City, Kyoto Prefecture.

sen.j: また、京都府京都市右京区の善入山宝筐院。
sen.e: Also, Zennyuzan Hokyoin Temple in Kyoto's Ukyo Ward.
Also, Zennyuzan Hokyoin Temple in Ukyo Ward, Kyoto City, Kyoto Prefecture.
sen.cmt: 京都府京都市右京区とあるので補足。
sen.e: Also, Zennyuzan Hokyoin Temple in Ukyo Ward, Kyoto City, Kyoto Prefecture.

sen.j: また、静岡県三島市川原ケ谷の地福山宝鏡院。
sen.e: Also, Jifukuzan Hokyoin Temple in Kawaharagaya, Mishima City, Shizuoka Prefecture.
sen.cmt: これで良いと思うが、地福山の読み方の裏付け見つからず。
sen.e: Also, Jifukuzan Hokyoin Temple in Kawaharagaya, Mishima City, Shizuoka Prefecture.
Also, Jifukuzan Hokyoin Temple in Kawaharagaya, Mishima City, Shizuoka Prefecture.

sen.j: 木像：等持院所蔵。
sen.e: Wooden Statue: In the collection of Toujiin Temple
Wooden Statue: In the collection of Toujiin Temple
Wooden Statue: In the collection of Toujiin Temple

sen.j: 江戸時代末期に尊皇攘夷派により尊氏、義満の木像と合わせて三条河原に梟首される事件が起こる（足利三代木像梟首事件）。
sen.e: At the end of the Edo period there was an incident in which the head was displayed, along with those of the portraits of Takauji and Yoshimitsu, by the nationalist faction (Ashikaga Shogun Portrait Pillory Incident).

At the end of the Edo period there was an incident in which the head was displayed on the dry bed of the Kamo-gawa River, along with the wooden statues of Takauji and Yoshimitsu, by Sonno-Joi faction (Ashikaga Shogun Portrait Pillory Incident).
sen.cmt: 尊王攘夷派 (Sonno-Joi faction)→Revere the Emperor, Expel the Barbarians-one of the political movements of the late Tokugawa period. 天皇の権威の絶対化と開国反対を主張した。単なるNationalistとは違うので、修正。 三条河原 (当時の処刑場で、賀茂川の河原にあった）部分が抜けていたので補足。 木像→wooden statue
sen.e: At the end of the Edo period there was an incident in which the head was displayed on the dry bed of the Kamo-gawa River, along with the wooden statues of Takauji and Yoshimitsu, by Sonno-Joi faction (Ashikaga Shogun Portrait Pillory Incident).

sen.j: 古典『太平記』では、酒色に溺れた愚鈍な人物として描かれている。
sen.e: In the classic Taiheiki, he is drawn as a silly person, indulging in drink.
In the classic Taiheiki, he is drawn as a silly person, indulging in drink.
In the classic Taiheiki, he is drawn as a silly person, indulging in drink.

sen.j: また、太平記は、義詮が没し細川頼之が管領に就任する章（巻第三十七）で物語を終えている。
sen.e: Moreover, the Taiheiki ends the story in the chapter wherein Yoshiakira dies and Yoriyuki HOSOKAWA advances to Kanrei (317).
Moreover, the Taiheiki ends the story in the chapter wherein Yoshiakira dies and Yoriyuki HOSOKAWA advances to Kanrei (Vol.37).
Moreover, the Taiheiki ends the story in the chapter wherein Yoshiakira dies and Yoriyuki HOSOKAWA advances to Kanrei (Vol.37).

sen.j: （官職位階履歴）
sen.e: (Offices and Ranks)
(Offices and Ranks)
(Offices and Ranks)

sen.j: ※日付＝旧暦
sen.e: NB: Dates are in the old calendar.
NB: Dates are in the old calendar.
NB: Dates are in the old calendar.

sen.j: 1335年（建武 (日本)2年）4月7日、従五位下に叙す。
sen.e: 1335 (Kenbu 2) April 7 - Awarded Junior 5th Class, Minor.
1335 (Kenbu 2) April 7 - Awarded Ju-Goi-ge (Junior 5th Class, Minor).
sen.cmt: 日本語での言い方を補足。
sen.e: April 7, 1335 - Awarded Ju-Goi-ge (Junior 5th Class, Minor).

sen.j: 1344年（興国5年/康永3年）3月16日、正五位下に昇叙。
sen.e: 1344 (Koukoku 5/Kouei 3) March 16 - Advanced to Senior 5th Class, Minor.
1344 (Koukoku 5/Kouei 3) March 16 - Advanced to Sho-Goi-ge (Senior 5th Class, Minor).
sen.cmt: 日本語での言い方を補足。
sen.e: March 16, 1344 - Advanced to Sho-Goi-ge (Senior 5th Class, Minor).

sen.j: 3月18日、左馬頭に任官。
sen.e: March 18 - Appointed Samanokami.
March 18 - Appointed Samanokami.
March 18 - Appointed Samanokami.

sen.j: 1347年（正平 (日本)2年/貞和3年）12月3日、従四位下に昇叙。
sen.e: 1347 (Shohei 2/Jowa 3) December 3 - Advanced to Junior 4th Class, Minor.
1347 (Shohei 2/Jowa 3) December 3 - Advanced to Ju-Shii-ge (Junior 4th Class, Minor).
sen.cmt: 日本語での言い方を補足。
sen.e: December 3, 1347 - Advanced to Ju-Shii-ge (Junior 4th Class, Minor).

sen.j: 1350年（正平5年/観応元年）8月22日、参議に補任し、左近衛中将を兼任。
sen.e: 1350 (Shohei 5/Kano 1) August 22 - Appointed Sangi, also acted as Sakonoechujo.
1350 (Shohei 5/Kano 1) August 22 - Appointed Sangi, also acted as Sakonoechujo.
August 22, 1350 - Appointed Sangi, also acted as Sakonoechujo.

sen.j: 1356年（正平11年/延文元年）8月23日、従三位に昇叙。
sen.e: 1356 (Shohei 11/Enbun 1) August 23 - Advanced to Junior 3rd Class.
1356 (Shohei 11/Enbun 1) August 23 - Advanced to Ju-Sanmi (Junior 3rd Class).
sen.cmt: 日本語での言い方を補足。従三位→Ju Sanmi が正しい。
sen.e: August 23, 1356 - Advanced to Ju-Sanmi (Junior 3rd Class).

sen.j: 参議左近衛中将如元。
sen.e: Remains Sangi Sakonoechujo
Remains Sangi, Sakonoechujo
Remains Sangi, Sakonoechujo

sen.j: 1358年（正平13年/延文3年）12月18日、征夷大将軍宣下
sen.e: 1358 (Shohei 13/Enbun 3) December 18 - Made Seii Taishogun
1358 (Shohei 13/Enbun 3) December 18 - Made Seii Taishogun
December 18, 1358 - Made Seii Taishogun

sen.j: 1359年（正平14年/延文4年）2月4日、武蔵守兼任。
sen.e: 1359 (Shohei 14/Enbun 4) February 4 - Concurrently served as Musashi no Kami
1359 (Shohei 14/Enbun 4) February 4 - Concurrently served as Musashi no Kami
February 4, 1359 - Concurrently served as Musashi no Kami

sen.j: 1363年（正平18年/貞治2年）1月28日、権大納言に転任。
sen.e: 1363 (Shohei 18/Joji 2) January 28 - Switched to post of Gondainagon
1363 (Shohei 18/Joji 2) January 28 - Switched to post of Gon dainagon
January 28, 1363 - Switched to post of Gon dainagon

sen.j: 7月29日、従二位に昇叙。
sen.e: July 29 - Advanced to Junior 2nd Class
July 29 - Advanced to Ju-Nii (Junior 2nd Class).
sen.cmt: 日本語での言い方を補足。
sen.e: July 29 - Advanced to Ju-Nii (Junior 2nd Class).

sen.j: 権大納言如元。
sen.e: Remains Gondainagon
Remains Gon-dainagon
sen.cmt: Gondainagon→Gon-dainagon 権とは権(かり)という意味。
sen.e: Remains Gon-dainagon

sen.j: 1367年（正平22年/貞治6年）1月5日、正二位に昇叙。
sen.e: 1367 (Shohei 22/Joji 6) January 5 - Advanced to Senior 2nd Class
1367 (Shohei 22/Joji 6) January 5 - Advanced to Sho-Nii (Senior 2nd Class).
sen.cmt: 日本語での言い方を補足。
sen.e: January 5, 1367 - Advanced to Sho-Nii (Senior 2nd Class).

sen.j: 12月7日、薨去。
sen.e: December 7 - Died
December 7 - Died
December 7 - Died

sen.j: 12月20日、贈従一位左大臣。
sen.e: December 20 - Made Junior 1st Class Minister of the Left
December 20 - Made Ju-Ichii Sadaijin (Junior 1st Class Minister of the Left).
sen.cmt: 日本語での言い方を補足。
sen.e: December 20 - Made Ju-Ichii Sadaijin (Junior 1st Class Minister of the Left).
